item.title: Covid: Matt Hancock defends timing of first lockdown
item.description: Ministers found it difficult to defy scientific advice as the pandemic began, says the health secretary.

item.title: Maya Forstater: Woman wins tribunal appeal over transgender tweets
item.description: Maya Forstater lost her job at a think tank over tweets saying people cannot change their biological sex.

item.title: Girls asked for nudes by up to 11 boys a night, Ofsted finds
item.description: Sexual harassment is being "normalised" among school-age children, England's schools watchdog finds.

item.title: Ex-Brewdog staff allege culture of fear at brewer
item.description: Former employees allege "cult of personality" in firm and claim "toxic attitude" to junior staff.

item.title: Crocodile attack: Twin Melissa Laurie is out of her coma
item.description: Melissa Laurie's twin says she is still in hospital after the attack in Mexico but is "much better".

item.title: US overtakes UK as hardest hit by Covid deaths in G7
item.description: UK pandemic deaths are the second worst of the seven big Western economies, an analysis for the BBC says.

item.title: 'Miraculous' mosquito hack cuts dengue by 77%
item.description: Infecting the mosquitoes with a different bug slams the brakes on dengue fever, trial finds.

item.title: Hospital waiting list tops 5m in England
item.description: But number of people waiting over a year drops for first time since pandemic began.

item.title: BBC radio presenter Dom Busby dies after illness
item.description: BBC radio presenter Dom Busby dies at the age of 53 after a short illness.

item.title: A40 crash: Family died when car swerved head-on into lorry
item.description: A coroner hears fatigue or distraction may have caused Zoe Powell to swerve the family's car.

item.title: Italian woman wakes up after 10 months in coma
item.description: Cristina Rosi, 37, was seven months pregnant when she suffered a heart attack in July last year.

item.title: In pictures: Solar eclipse as seen from the UK
item.description: Some parts of the world have seen the annular eclipse, but from the UK there has been a partial solar eclipse.

item.title: The Beast: How Biden's getting around on his first overseas trip
item.description: Planes, helicopters and armoured cars - how President Biden will travel on his first official trip.

item.title: Prince Edward congratulates Harry and Meghan on new baby
item.description: The Earl of Wessex spoke exclusively to the BBC on what would have been his father's 100th birthday.

item.title: My beautician saved my life from deadly skin cancer
item.description: Seonag was unaware she had a "mark" on the back of her thigh when she went for a Mother's Day massage.

item.title: G7: What it's all about in 60 seconds
item.description: Jon Kay tells us what is happening ahead of this weekend's G7 summit in just one minute.

item.title: Hitman's Wife's Bodyguard: Film sequel slated by critics
item.description: The movie sequel sees Samuel L Jackson, Salma Hayek and Ryan Reynolds reprise their roles.

item.title: Covid in India: The mother and son feeding Mumbai's poor
item.description: Harsh Mandavia and his mother have provided more than 25,000 meals to people hit by the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Sacred objects: From police evidence to museum pieces
item.description: Sacred objects seized from practitioners of Afro-Brazilian religions are being returned after decades.

item.title: Why classical musicians are performing among tombstones
item.description: The New York Philharmonic is back, playing to a live - and not-so-live - audience.

item.title: Sweet dreams! Wandering elephants take a snooze
item.description: A herd of 15 elephants on the move is China has been spotted having a nap in a forest.

item.title: 'Summit security feels like another lockdown'
item.description: The G7 summit is being held in a remote part of Cornwall, and has divided opinion amongst locals.

item.title: Covid: Things are looking up for Bolton, eye of the variant storm
item.description: Bolton had been "ground zero" for the new variant, but now cases have started to fall.

item.title: X-Press Pearl: The 'toxic ship' that caused an environmental disaster
item.description: The X-Press Pearl, off Sri Lanka, could be a threat to marine life and the fishing industry.

item.title: Covid-19: 'Our wedding changed more times than I can count'
item.description: Couples set to get married and the wedding industry face an anxious wait for restrictions to ease.

item.title: Why it is no longer cool to be a crazy rich Asian in China
item.description: Netizens are outraged by the sky-high incomes of some people in China amid a gaping wealth gap.

item.title: The dilemma of rebuilding Gaza without rearming Hamas
item.description: Donors are grappling with the challenge of helping Gaza without benefitting its militant rulers.

item.title: Keeping Up With the Kardashians: 8 ways one family became a hot topic
item.description: As the series ends, we look at how the Kardashians became an office cooler conversation.

item.title: 'I can speak freely and use swear words as I see fit'
item.description: The rise of email "newsletter" providers that allow writers to directly connect with readers.

item.title: Euro 2020: England, Scotland and Wales players who wouldn't have made it last year
item.description: With Covid pushing the Euros back, the England, Scotland and Wales squads look a bit different now.

item.title: Kenyan avocado farm faces more claims of abuse
item.description: As the company tries to win back the UK business it lost, more alleged victims have come forward.

item.title: Celtic: Ange Postecoglou confirmed as new manager of Scottish Premiership club
item.description: Ange Postecoglou is appointed as Celtic's new manager, with the former Australia boss leaving Yokohama F Marinos in Japan.

item.title: Groves quits Australian Olympic trials, citing 'misogynistic perverts' in sport
item.description: Australian swimmer Madeline Groves withdraws from Olympic trials, citing "misogynistic perverts" in the sport.

item.title: France to struggle & Foden to shine? - BBC pundits make Euro 2020 predictions
item.description: Who will win, and how will England, Scotland and Wales do? BBC pundits predict what will happen at Euro 2020

item.title: England v New Zealand: Dom Sibley, Zak Crawley & Joe Root lose wickets in quick succession
item.description: Captain Joe Root is caught behind for four, following quickly after the wickets of Dom Sibley and Zak Crawley as England are reduced to 85-3 by New Zealand in the second Test at Edgbaston.

item.title: When could social distancing end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine is being offered to over-18s in Wales and Northern Ireland, over-25s in England and over-30s in Scotland.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Covax: How many Covid vaccines have the US and the other G7 countries pledged?
item.description: The US is set to confirm it will give 500m doses of the Pfizer vaccine to the international Covax scheme.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Covid: What do we know about global youth unemployment?
item.description: Young people have suffered from the economic consequences of Covid.

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Covid rules are making things a bit different for Euro 2020 spectators.

item.title: Covid: How is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: A third Covid wave hit much of Europe hard but now gradually lockdowns are being eased.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now reaching younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The government is yet to decide whether to lift the remaining restrictions on 21 June

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Travel guide to Spain, Portugal, France and more holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about travelling abroad to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid Indian variant: Where is it, how does it spread and is it more infectious?
item.description: The Indian variant is spreading in some parts of the country - how serious is it?

item.title: Covid-19: Could a third wave change 21 June plans in England?
item.description: Rising coronavirus cases have called the planned 21 June relaxing of rules in England into question.

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Myanmar: The mysterious deaths of the NLD party officials
item.description: The deaths of officials from Aung San Suu Kyi's party has raised scrutiny of the military's actions.

item.title: Freddie Figgers: The millionaire tech inventor who was 'thrown away' as a baby
item.description: Entrepreneur Freddie Figgers says life has taught him that the important thing is people, not profits.

item.title: Valentina Petrillo: 'Better to be a slow happy woman than a fast unhappy man'
item.description: If Valentina Petrillo is selected for Italy's squad in Tokyo this year, she will be the first trans woman Paralympian.

item.title: The Motherload: How pandemic anger almost destroyed a mums' support group
item.description: Abusive messages from angry mums during lockdown almost caused the founder of The Motherload to close it down.

item.title: The children selling explicit videos on OnlyFans
item.description: British subscription site OnlyFans is failing to prevent underage users from selling and appearing in explicit videos, a BBC investigation has found.
